title: Daat Zkenim on Exodus
versionTitle: Yalkut, Sifsei Chachomim Chumash, Metsudah Publications, 2009
text: Adonoy is the righteous One. Pharaoh came to this realization in the plague of hailstones more than the other plagues, because Hashem told the Egyptians to shelter their flock, and all the animals that were not sheltered died. Therefore, Pharaoh said that Hashem is the righteous One because he was forewarned, “and I and my people are the sinners,” for in their wickedness they left their animals in the fields and did not believe.

For there was no house. Obviously there were homes in which no living first born was to be found at the time. The Sifri relates, however, that whenever a first born child of an Egyptian family died they would erect a statue of him. Then when the plague struck, these statues also either shattered or melted, which was as painful to the family as the day of the death. It is also taught that mice came and rummaged after the corpses of first born children that had been buried on the premises and this, too, was as painful for them as the day of their deaths.

Not one (literally, “until one”). In other words, one did remain alive—Pharaoh himself. Although in Tehillim (106:11) it is written, “not one of them remained,” that only means that no one remained of the hosts he brought with him.

He shall set him free. The Midrash explains that Cham was condemned to servitude because he gazed upon his father’s nakedness with his eyes and then related it to his brothers with his mouth. Therefore once the slave has been afflicted in his eyes or mouth he is set free.
I will hear for I am gracious. When the borrower cries out to Hashem to bless the lender for returning his garment, Hashem will hear him and have mercy upon the lender in return.

Gold, silver and copper. The charity that a person gives when he is healthy is likened to gold, while that which he gives when he is ailing is likened to silver and that which he leaves over in his will is likened to copper.

They shall make. Regarding all the other vessels it is written, “You shall make.” Only regarding the ark is it written, “They shall make.” The entire nation had to participate in the construction of the ark to show honor towards the Torah that was housed within it. This is a hint that all the residents of a town must show honor towards the Torah scholars among them by tending to their needs. Another reason that everyone had to help in the making of the ark was to ensure that all would have a share in the Torah’s reward.
Inside and out. According to Rova this is a hint that a scholar must be as righteous on the inside as he appears to be on the outside.
They must not be removed. Because of the great sanctity of the ark, Hashem did not want people to handle it in order to insert and remove the poles.

Out of acacia wood standing. The simple meaning is that it was forbidden to use wood from trees that had already fallen. Instead, they were required to cut down trees that were still standing. Alternatively, this is a hint that the components of the Tabernacle will “stand” (i.e. endure) forever. Thus even today they are still in existence, hidden away somewhere.

From evening to morning. According to Rashi it did not matter that extra oil would remain in the lamps after the short nights of summer. The Riva, however, considers it improbable that they would have wasted so much oil day after day. He suggests, therefore, that the thickness of the wick was varied to ensure that the oil would be consumed.

The rich shall not give more. This restriction was necessary in order that an accurate count could be deduced from number of coins. Alternatively, it was to prevent the rich from claiming a greater portion in the Mishkon.

But You did not let me know. All God said to him was, “Behold, My angel will go before you” (32:33). He did not even tell him which angel. Moreover, every person in the world is accompanied by an angel; so where was the evidence that he had “found favor” in God’s eyes?
Please let me know Your way. Accompany me in person and inform me of the way I am to go.
So that I will know. This is how I will know that I have indeed found favor in Your eyes.
Preserve the Festival of Matzos. That is, do not add any other festivals the way that you did in honor of the calf (see 32:5).
You must not kindle a fire. The Torah singled out kindling a fire for special mention because many people do not think of it as a craft.

See, Ad-noy has designated. Betzalel was Miriam’s grand-nephew (see Rashi); therefore some people complained that Moshe was assigning all the positions of authority to his family members. In response he said to them, “See (i.e. “Know”) that I did not choose Betzalel on my own, rather Hashem designated him by name”.
